comments.body: We shouldn't be adding content-specific rules to the validation code. Why not allow any non `@` prefixed string to be used for collections instead? That will preserve the more strict check for ansible-base while allowing collection authors more flexibility.
I'd be more than happy to do that. It doesn't look like there is branching logic for base vs collection in here now, yeah? I'd love a pointer as to how you think that should look.

When the schema is constructed we indicate if a collection is being tested:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/fc448ea54f1595e8d24e72abd9b5245ec6165842/test/lib/ansible_test/_data/sanity/validate-modules/validate_modules/schema.py#L327

You should be able to pass `for_collection` to `author` like we already do for `version`:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/fc448ea54f1595e8d24e72abd9b5245ec6165842/test/lib/ansible_test/_data/sanity/validate-modules/validate_modules/schema.py#L335
Sweet, thanks! And you think the collection one should basically just be "there should be an author string" Will update.
@gundalow @acozine What are your thoughts? Should we keep our current author restrictions for ansible-base and allow any value for author in collections?
I was totally working from a stale copy - my bad. The for_collection stuff is clear and obvious - when I'm actually up to date. :)
